titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Went to Boston with Mary Louisa—shaved at No 222 Washington street. Cadmus has removed to Cambridge a man by the name of Bogle now keeps the shop 222. which for about ten years has been my place for shaving in Boston— I returned to my Sons house no 57. Mount Vernon Street and from thence we returned to Quincy to dine. At five P.M. we took the Railroad train of Cars for Fall River J. Q Adams, Louisa Catherine Adams, Mrs. John Adams, Mary Louisa & Isaac Hull Adams, Mrs. Eleanor Goods, Margaret Delany—and William Wheeler Coachman, eight persons— Lieut Joseph Harrod Adams goes with us as far as New York. It seemed to me on leaving home as if it was upon my last great journey— At 7. P.M. we reached Fall River and embarked in the Steamer Bay State. had but one moment to shake hands with Mr. Nathaniel Borden. We had a fine night, a brisk breeze but it was so dark that I saw nothing of the place and have no more idea of it than I ever had. The Boat is a remarkably fine one but I very soon turned in for the night to bed.

Our passage during the first part of the night particularly sound. Point Judith was somewhat
rough and our fresh water sailor passengers were all seasick, but I slept it away in bed till near daylight this morning when we had got into the East River beyond Sands Point and approaching Hurl Gate, when a thick fog came up which brought us to lay to till long after sunrise. As the fog dispersed the Bay State resumed her course and about noon we landed in the North River and took lodgings at the Astor House— At the Astor House we found Mrs. Alexander. B. Johnson of Utica and her brother Mr. Masters. William C. Johnson was married last night to Miss Harriet Douw of Albany and they are expected to arrive here next Thursday and to embark for England next Monday. Alexander. S. Johnson called on us— Our ladies went to the Theater to see the French Ballet Dancers. Mr. John Jay and Mr. Beakman came, and took me with them to attend a numerous meeting of the New York Historical Society at which Albert Gallatin presided, and where several interesting Papers were read. My meeting with Mr. Gallatin was very pleasant and cordial— He Presided at the Meeting as if he had been forty years of age— I got home about ten P.M—

Past the day at New York suffering as if every day would be my last and yet as if I were in the prime of life— We had very indifferent chambers given us yesterday and better this day— Mrs. DeWindt who has come and taken lodgings for the Winter in the City with her daughter Isabella and two children a boy and a girl of her other daughter the widow Mrs. Louisa Whittemore called on us. Mrs. Whittemore being detained at
home by indisposition. Mr. Furman a gentleman to whom Isabella is engaged to be married also called. I had also visits from Mr. Arnold Buffam and sundry others whose names I do not recollect. The day slipt away I know not how suffering severely all the time with the tooth ache and feeling as if I was gradually breathing my last. Notwithstanding which, I went with the Ladies in the Evening to the Opera the Somnambula the part of Amina by Madame Anna Bishop, and the mad Musician from which we returned to our lodgings about eleven P.M.

At nine this morning we crossed the River to Jersey City and took the Railway Cars for Philadelphia where we arrived at two P.M. and took our lodgings at what was Jone’s Union Hotel— Still called by his name but he is no longer there I walked immediately alone to the Bank of North America which is still in Chesnut Street but on the other side of the Street from where it was before, and I received 150 dollars in gold for five Coupons of thirty dollars each on Cincinnati Bonds payable the first of November 1847— We dined and spent the Eveg at Philadelphia— Joseph Adams left us this morning

I had a tolerably quiet night and at eight oclock this morning we left the house still called Jones Hotel at Philadelphia and now kept as an appendage to the United States Hotel. We took this morning the Train of Railroad Cars for Baltimore, where we arrived at two oclock and found our friend Christopher Hughes as we alighted at the American House opposite the Railway Depot. There
we dined and after dinner Mr. Hughes called on us again with his Daughter Margaret— I was tortured with the tooth ache and Margaret Delany had been seized with violent Cramps in the Cars this morning before we reached Baltimore— We took the Train for Washington which started at five P.M. and notwithstanding sundry obstacles and delays we reached our house in F street Washington about eight oclock this Evening. All safe, blessed be the name of God. Mrs. Swift wife of Capt Swift had travelled with us from U.S.

Thanks to Almighty God that I am yet alive—and may I be ready to surrender my soul at His call whenever it shall come— Mr. Frye called to see us this day Dr. Gunnell extracted the tooth from my head which relieved me from immediate and severe suffering I called at the Bank of the Metropolis and deposited two hundred Dollars in gold. One hundred and fifty of which I received at Philadelphia and fifty from my son at Boston—

Sleep till daylight relaxation from excessive stricture, otherwise no better than for the last six months Attended Public worship at Saint Johns Church 23d. Sunday after Trinity— Mr. Pyne preached from Phillippians 3.17. [“]Brethren be followers together of me and mark them which walk so, as ye have us for an ensample” and he administered the Communion after the Sermon, to the part of which, I did not stay— After dinner he preached from John 10.14. [“]I know my sheep.” from which words Mr. Pyne
drew in irresistible conclusion of the Divinity of Jesus—but from which a very different conclusion might be drawn Mr. Pynes preaching always breeds in my mind an irresistible doubt whether he believes what he says. Evening visits from Mrs. Turnbull and her daughter Catherine, Mrs. Swift, Miss Abert daughter of Col Abert and Mr. Moody—

I awoke in time to hear the clock strike four. slept again rose about seven. warm and fine weather. My disability mental and bodily surpasses my power of expression and my conception—forgiveness and mercy is all that I can even pray for and in that spirit I must abide my time— Call at the Bank of the Metropolis drew one hundred dollars and paid to Mrs. John Adams for household expenses At the Franklin Insurance Company Office received four hundred and seventy five dollars in Virginia Bills the Dividend payable on the first of this month At the Bank of Washington received two hundred and twenty five dollars in Bills being the Dividends on Washington City Corporation six per cent stocks for the first of July and first of October 1847. At the National Intelligencer Office were I saw Joseph Gales and had some conversation with him— Received Eveg visits from Mr. Larned, Mary E. E. Cutts, Mr. Charles Gilpin of Philadelphia, and Mr. Allen the minister of the Unitarian Church.

Summer weather—slept till I heard the clock strike three—then slept again till daylight. The Journey from home appears to have left my health much in the state that it was there, the prospect of life continuing as from day to day— Call at Bank of the Metropolis, deposited
from the Franklin Insurance Company four hundred and seventy five dollars, and from the Washington Bank of City Corporation Stock two hundred and twenty five dollars. Dr. Thomas. B. J. Frye was here this morning. I received a visit from J. Erving Duncan styling himself a Nephew of General Irvin the late Whig Candidate for the Office of Governor of Pennsylvania I enquired of Mr. Duncan if he had any particular object in paying me this visit—he said no, but I suppose him to be in search of some Office. I received visits also from Commodore Morris, Rev Smith Pyne, and Judge Wm. Cranch at whose house I called yesterday but he was then in attendance on his Court— I received a card from C. S. Whitney Doorkeeper of the House of Representatives. I suppose he means in expectancy I received also 21. Volumes of Documents of the last and preceeding Session of Congress. Ride after dinner till sunset. Isaac Hull Adams is employed in the Service of the Coast Survey

Brown the Barber comes to me every third day. I had a tolerable quiet night and am able to dress myself with some assistance from Mrs. Goods—and with that of my Grand Daughter Mary Louisa I resumed my Diary from the first of this month. took a long morning walk and visited Mrs. Madison with whom I found her niece Miss Anna Payne—both in good health. Enos Ray came with a Bill of $89.51 cents for keeping a pair of horses from the first of June to the first of November which I paid by Check on the Bank of Metropolis. No ride in the Carriage and no visitors this day.

A not very quiet night, nor so promising as those which have preceded it— I received visits from Phosius Kavasales
stationed at the Navy Yard as Chaplain from Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, and his sister Miss Virginia Tayloe Dr. John. M. Thomas was here this Evening—very unwell—which has been the occasion of his not coming before. Cards from Mr. Clingman. I received a Letter from Elisha Whittlesey General Agent of the Board of Managers of the National Washington Monument Society enclosing copies of three Resolutions adopted at a meeting of the 2d. of this month of the Board of Managers. First that the Corner stone of the proposed Monument be laid on the 22d. of February next provided a suitable site can be obtained in time. Second that a Committee to consist of the mayor the first Vice President and the General Agent Whittlesey be appointed to apply to Congress early in the Session for a suitable site in the public mall for the proposed Monument and that the said Committee be requested to apply to the Hon John Quincy Adams to deliver an Address on the occasion of laying the Corner Stone. Third. That a Committee be appointed to make the necessary arrangements for the ceremony of laying the Corner Stone of the proposed Monument— I regret that I am physically disabled from performing the duty which I am requested to undertake by the extinction of my voice. Just before noon, I rode to the Astronomical Observatory where I found Lieut M. F. Maury and sundry other Officers and inspected the following Instruments. One the West Transit Instrument. 2. The Prime Vertical Transit Instrument. 3. The Mural Circle. 4. The Meridian Circle. 5. The Refraction Circle. received and mounted since I left this place last June— 6. The Equatorial. but none of them in a condition to take an Observation at mid day I called at Commodore Morris but he was not at home. The day was fine but cooler than it has been for several preceding days
As quiet a night as will ever fall to my lot hereafter. Morning visits from Col Haine and Ashbury Dickins Secretary of the Senate. Walk as far as the City

Dr. John M. Thomas was here and upon consultation gave me medical advice. He was here also in the evening on a friendly visit with his father. I had also a morning visit from Stephen Douglass now a Senator from the State of Illinois. I received a Letter from Aaron Leggett with a printed memorial from him to Congress stating his Claims upon Mexico—

Unquiet and half sleepless night. Morning visit from Dr. Todson. Received Littells Living Age No 183. My wife had a Letter from Mrs. C. F. Adams with a Bill of Lading for a box of merchandise by the schooner Harriet from Boston. The Letter mentions the unfortunate marriage of Miss Louisa Wales, to a man by the name of Kimball, who failed upon the day of his marriage. I called at the General Post Office. Cave Johnson the Post Master General was absent in Cabinet meeting at the President’s. I saw the 2nd. assistant Post master General B. F. Brown and left with him A Tillinghasts Letter on the location of the Post Office at West Wrentham. Walk home met Arthur Stansbury the Reporter, who walked home with me but did not come in. Afternoon ride till sunset.

Twenty-fourth Sunday after Trinity—heard Mr. Pyne in the morning from 2d Corinthians 7.10. For Godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of. But the sorrow of the world worketh death And in the Afternoon from John 8.11. “Neither do I condemn thee go and sin no more.” After the Evening Service we took a short ride.

An uncomfortable and restless night. Brother Paul and Brother Bernard Monks of the order of Saint Francis from the County of Galway Ireland came introduced by Mr. Joyce my neighbor and Mr.. They brought Certificates from W. Matthews Rector of St Patricks Church and James P. Donellan Rector of St Matthews Church in this City. They are making collections for the relief of the distressed in Ireland. I settled the account with Isaac Hull Adams for the expenses of the Journey from Quincy to Washington. first to the fifth of November 1847. amount of the expense One hundred and forty-two dollars and thirty cents. I gave a check to I. H. Adams for fifty seven dollars and thirty cents on the Bank of the Metropolis for the Balance due to him. I received a pamphlet of Observations on the Aboriginal Monuments of the Mississippi Valley by E. G. Squier. I called at the Navy Department to see the Secretary John. Y. Mason. But he had just gone over to the Presidents. Dr. Thomas was here and gave me medical advice. Evening visit from my neighbour Albert K. Parris second Comptroller of the Treasury.

I called at the Navy Department to see the Secretary of the Navy but he was in Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— I met in the street Lewis. C. Levin the native American Member from Philadelphia. at Coleman’s Hotel and left a Card for Stephen. A. Douglass Senator from the State of Illinois. I also met Lieut Maury and agreed to Call at the Observatory this Evening to view the moon through the Equatorial if the Sky should prove bright. At six oclock P.M. I went accordingly it being the ninth day of the Moon and the Sky sufficiently
clear to look at the Moon, but thickning with haze till nothing distinct was to be seen and I came home before eight oclock. Lieut Maury promised to call on me the first clear Evening. But Astronomical Observation is always liable to disappointment from transient clouds— Lieut Maury told me that of seventeen Officers attached to the Observatory in 1846 scarcely one was now left but another set had taken their places. The appearance of the Moon as viewed through eye pieces of different magnifying power differs totally from its aspect to the naked eye. The appearance of the Disk resembles on its surface much to that of a plum Cake crusted with sugar. with great and extraordinary irregularities on the surface and several seeming holes going into impenetrable darkness. There is nothing resembling water and nothing having an appearance of vegetation, the general impression that it gives is of lifeless barrenness—the question whether it has any atmosphere remains unsettled. Mrs. Maury and several ladies and gentlemen came in as I came away. Mr. Maury spoke of Prof Pierce’s questions whether the Planet Neptune is really the Planet discovered by the previous calculations of Leverrier Its Orbit is not yet ascertained though inferred by approximation from the fact ascertained by Mr. Sears. J. Walker that the star was observed by the French Astronomer Lalande on the 8th. of May 1795. Three additional Planets named Astria, Hebe, and Iris have been discovered within the last two years— They are parts of that supposed exploded Planet between Mars and Jupiter of which four had been previously discovered and called Asteroids. Mr. Maury supposes that there are perhaps many more fragments of this Planet to be discovered hereafter.

A man by the name of William M. Thomas with a Commission as Acting Boatswain in the Navy and another as Prize master of a
Mexican Vessel came with his papers and requested my assistance in support of his Claims in the Navy Department. I called accordingly at the Department but the Secretary was in Cabinet Meeting at the President’s. I rode to the Capitol and took out of the Congress Library an Edition of Pliny’s Letters and The Panegyric of Trajan with a French translation by De sassis. No English Translation of the Panegyric here. I took out also the second Volume of the English translation of Plato, by Floyer Sydenham and Thomas Taylor. in five Volumes Quarto. I took the second for the Timeus. I met at the House Mr. George. P. Marsh Member from the State of Vermont. Marked the time by the Dial of the House. I asked Mr. Marsh what was the meaning of the Dog days, as noted in our Common Almanacs, & said I considered their statements as impositions. He referred me to the Conversation Lexicon—which like all other Almanac statement of the Dog Days is false— I received a Letter from Col A. P. Hayne with a printed pamphlet being a Brief Sketch of his Life and Military Services.

I called this morning at the Navy Department and saw the Secretary John. Y. Mason. I spoke to him of the Claim of Wm. M. Thomas whose Papers I left with him. to which he promised to pay immediate attention. I spoke to him also of the Astronomical Observatory and of my earnest desire that an Appropriation may be made at the approaching Session of Congress for the annual composition and publication of an Nautical Almanac like that published in England and like the Connaissance des Temps Annually published in France. He read to me an extract of his Report to the President of the last year in which an appropriation was recommended for the publication of a Nautical Almanac which was accordingly proposed in the estimates of the Navy Department but which was
accordingly proposed in the estimates of the Navy Department but which was struck out by the House He said he should renew the recommendation of the appropriation in the estimates for the approaching Session of Congress. Mr. Mason gave me also a Copy of his Address before the Alumni Association of the University of North Carolina. Delivered in Gerard Hall on the 2nd. of June last. the Evening before their Commencement Day. My wife dined at her sister Mrs. Fryes. The day was fair and the sky bright until the Evening. I intended to have paid another visit to the Observatory but as night came on the sky clouded up and after calling at Mr. Fryes, I returned home. postponing the visit to the Observatory. I returned the visit of Col Hayne by card left at his lodgings at Mrs. Ulrichs. I read something of the Panegyric of Trajan, and something of Taylor’s Translation of the Timeus of Plato—

Called at the Navy Department and left with the Secretary a charge of W. M. Thomas against the Government for two months service $50—which I had yesterday inadvertently left upon my table when I took his other papers to the Department— An orphan boy thirteen or fourteen years of age came with certificates of recommendation from James F Donellan Director of St Matthews Church—and N. Callen to procure for the boy whom they name Joseph J. Head employment— What he himself wants is to be appointed a Page in the House of Representatives. he says his name is Joseph Hill that his father was a Baptist minister who has been dead these five years and his mother died long before—that his present employment is to carry round the Baltimore Clipper for distributing which he pays the
Publisher weekly and he pays two dollars a week for his board— I told him I would help him to get the appointment of a Page if I could, and bade him come to me again next Wednesday General Jesup and two of his daughters Lucy Ann and Jane paid us an evening visit. I answered Col Arthur. P. Hayne’s Letter thanking him for the present of his Autobiography

Beautiful weather but no abatement of my complaints my weakness increases— Wm. M Thomas was here but the Secretary of the Navy has not yet decided on his claims for arrears of payment and for appointment as Boatswain in the Navy—he is impatient to go to his family in Baltimore. I rode to the Capitol and walked home— I met at the Post Office of H.R.U.S. Robert Barnwell Rhett of South Carolina who was courteous and civil. B. B. French had gone to the Penitentiary, took a pen knife—compared my watch with the dial. My Sonnet was taken away last Winter— Walking home I met Arthur Stansbury the Reporter and John. W. Davis of Indiana Speaker of H.R.U.S. at the last or 29th. Congress. Not a member of the 30th. Congress. He told me he lodged where he always had at Mr. Leonard Harbaugh’s in eighth Street. After dinner ride with my Wife and Mary and then I went alone to the Observatory. Viewed through the Equatorial with Lieut Maury and Professor Hubbard the full moon, the planets Neptune, Iris, Mars and Saturn with his ring and one satellite. Viewed also through the west Transit Instrument the Transit of two Stars— Lieut Maury told me he was writing me a long Letter and he would soon invite me to look at the Nebulae in Orion. I came home about 8. oclock. Visit from Charles. B. King the Painter.

Eruption round my right knee I went with Isaac Hull Adams to the Unitarian
Church where Mr. Allen preached from Matthew 24.14. “And this Gospel of the Kingdom shall be preached in all the World, for a witness unto all nations, and then shall the end come.” A very excellent Discourse characterizing with discrimination the peculiarity of the unpremeditated words of Christ with his confident assurance that Heaven and Earth shall pass away but that his word should not pass away— I walked home, and in the afternoon attended at St John’s Church where Mr. Pyne read the Evening Service for the 25th. Sunday after Trinity and preached from Revelation 3.18. I counsel thee, to buy of me gold tried in the fire that thou mayest be rich. The subject of the Discourse was the close of the Ecclesiastical year and the approaching commencement of a new year. The next Sunday being the first Sunday of Advent. It was of course a common place of lamentation over the past and earnest exhortation for the future— Notice was given of Thanksgiving next Thursday and a collection to be taken up.

Heard the Clock strike four A.M. Thomas Duckett a negro soliciting contributions to purchase his freedom and that of his family. Also for another family. B. B. French Clerk of the House of Representatives and C. S. Whitney Door Keeper of the House of Representatives were here. He told me there was one vacancy in the list of the Pages of the House and he would appoint Joseph Hill to fill it. but it must depend upon the Door Keeper who may be elected at the meeting of the House to confirm or annul the appointment— I returned the visit of Mr. John. W. Davis by leaving a card at his lodgings at Leonard Harbaugh’s. Evening visits from Lieut Whipple and Richard. D. Cutts. I received a Letter from John. P. Kennedy recommending Mr. Williams for the Office of Sergeant at Arms— My wife had a bad fall this day
and hurt her face which almost crazed me I took a ride this afternoon. Miss Mary Hayne and her brother A. B. Hayne were here.

Succession of visitors. Among the rest two from Virginia named Cleighton and Robinson. Cleighton came to solicit my vote for his Father as Keeper of the Post Office of H.R.U.S. Also two Quakers or Friends one named David Adams from Madison County N.Y. the other Lewis from Pennsylvania. David Adams was very inquisitive of Genealogy and spoke of four Generations of his own name ending in Connecticut and New York but not of the Henry Adams race. Mary Louisa went as a Bridesmaid to the wedding of Miss Juliana Randall.

Warm rain night and morning. I received yesterday an invitation from Messrs. Willard to the opening Dinner of the City Hotel this day at 4. P.M. I have an invitation from S. Draper junr. Charles A Peabody, John Thomas, B. W. Binney, and L. B. Winard, a Committee of the New England Society of the City of New York to the dinner at the Astor House on the 22d. of December next, which I am to decline— A Letter from E. C. Wines of Burlington New Jersey about a normal School for that State and my opinion is asked upon this subject— Letter from G. V. Washington Georgetown 22d. Novr. 1847, declaring himself a Candidate for the appointment of Sergeant at Arms. of H.R.U.S— and an invitation from Col J. J. Abert for Saturday Evening at six oclock.— I called at Colemans Hotel to see Mrs. George Barkman and her Son and daughter
but they had left the City day before yesterday in the Steamer for Richmond Virginia Mary Louisa dined with the Bridal Party at Mr. Thomas Munroe’s.

Thanksgiving Day— At the Unitarian Church Mr. Allen preached a Sermon of Thanksgiving for the enjoyment of blessings National and Individual, but he touched upon no Political topic and he delivered his text in so low a tone of voice that I did not hear whence it was taken—but its reference was to the Land flowing with milk and honey. We had visits from Col Arthur. P. Hayne, and Mrs. Hayne. Dr. Thomas was also here and prescribed for my wife who is suffering from her fall, and for me. He spoke to me also of an Article in the Baltimore Sun Newspaper of Tuesday last attributing to me certain opinions respecting the War and prospects of Peace with Mexico— I received a Circular Letter from the President of Harvard University Edward Everett inviting me as one of the Subscribers to the Fund for the purchase of the large Telescope, which has recently been resumed at Cambridge to visit the Observatory with any members of my family on Monday Evening the 20th. of December or should the Evening prove unfavorable on the first clear Evening of the week preceding any full moon. Mrs. John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa spent the Evening at Mrs. Randalls—

Morning walk round 4 1/2 Street Church. I met Thomas. L. Clingman a Whig member from the State of North Carolina of the 28th. Congress
who lost his election in the 29th. and is now returned again a member elect of the 30th. I met also Sargent of Philadelphia— I had received a Letter from him soliciting my vote for him as Clerk of the House. I told him I should be glad to vote for him, but my vote was pledged. He thought circumstances might occur to modify my intentions, to which I assented but said that I never had approved the principle of turning out a competent incumbent of public Officers to substitute another on Party Principles— He said he knew that but French himself had acted upon other principles— I told him I understood Mr. French had been misrepresented on this subject—which French told me himself, and that he had been charged with dismissing Officers whom he had on the contrary, labored assiduously to retain. It is however very apparent that this election of all the Officers of the House will be carried by the screws of the Whig Party. I suppose they will be applied for Matthew St. Clair Clarke and there is little chance therefore for Mr. Sargent. He walked with me to the door of my house, but declined to come in. I took a ride with my wife and Grand Daughter this Evening. We had no visitors— I received a Letter from G. W. Hill of Ashland Ohio full of political speculations to which he requests my answer. I began but did not finish a Letter to Elisha Whittlesey General agent of the Board of Managers of the National Monument Society.

I told Miss Stafford that Mr. Palfrey was a member elect of the 30th. Congress and that she would do well to apply to him for assistance in support of her claims if as I hoped he should be here at the opening of the Session, which I was sorry to say was very doubtful, as I am informed he was very ill a few days since. Morning walk round 4 1/2 Street. Evening Party of men at Col. J. J. Abert’s I went at half past seven and came
home about nine oclock before supper— Mary Louisa spent the Evening at Mrs. Randall’s—

At the Unitarian Church in the morning Mr. Allen preached from John 3.11. “Verily verily I say unto thee we speak that we do know and testify that we have seen.[”] At St. Johns Church it was Advent Sunday my wife went and took the Communion. There was no Sermon after Dinner there but catechizing the children— In the Evening at 7 oclock I went again to the Unitarian Church where Mr. Allen preached from Matthew 6.25 “Therefore I say unto you take no thought for your life what ye shall eat or what ye shall drink, nor yet for your body what ye shall put on. is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment.”— Isaac Hull Adams went with me and we came home about nine o’clock.

A night mare in morning sleep I called at the Office of Stephen Pleasanton the Fifth Auditor with a Letter from Wm. B. Duggan of Quincy in behalf of Capt Charles Swift for the appointment of Keeper of the Light House on Minotts Ledge at the Cohasset Rocks. The recommendation had been sent to the Secretary of the Treasury the 23d. of October. Mr. Pleasanton referred me to Mr. McGinnis at the Treasury Department— The Secretary Mr. Walker was at the Presidents. Mr. McGinnis said the recommendations would be laid before him for his consideration. Ride to the Capitol where I compared my Chronometer with the Dial of H.R.U.S. and lost my glove. In the Evening we had a visit from Mr. John. A. Rockwell member elect for H.R.U.S from State of Connecticut. He arrived
here this morning— Mary Louisa went to the Railway Depot expecting the arrival of her friend Louise Agniel with Mr. Schenck member of H.R.U.S. from Ohio, but they did not come

I have very indifferent nights but not entirely without sleep, and I have now visits more numerous than I can recollect or recall, chiefly from Members of Congress arriving from day to day, from Candidates for the Offices to be elected by the House of Representatives and from mendicants of all descriptions, some for money, some for place, and not a few for both. This day I had a visit from Mr. Otho. H. Williams candidate for the Office of Sergeant at Arms of the House, in whose favor I had already received a Letter from my friend John. P. Kennedy, and I received this day a printed recommendation of W. W. Seaton the mayor of the City and five others, and a statement by himself that he is the Son of James Moorhead of Indiana, Pennsylvania who was removed from Office in this City by R. J. Walker This recommendation was for the Office of Sergeant at Arms— I rode to the Capitol, and enquired in the Clerk’s Office of the House if I had left my glove there, but did not find it— I walked home which was almost as much as I could perform. Mr. Archibald Campbell and his wife spent part of the Evening here. He is the Chief Clerk of the Secretary of War W. L. Marcy
